subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove and today I'd like to pay a tribute to one of the great
parapsychological writers of all time, my distant cousin, D. Scott Rogo.
Scott has published over 20 books, written hundreds of articles in the field of parapsychology
and psychical research.
Tragically, he was murdered in 1990 at the age of 40.
Before he died, Scott and I collaborated on one book together, which never was published
in the form in which we wrote it.
It was called Earth's Ambassador and it was the story of Ted Owens who later became the
subject of my book, The PK Man.
In fact, I borrowed heavily from the original unpublished manuscript that Scott and I had
created.
So, he is really the unacknowledged, except in the acknowledgments, co-author of The PK
Man.
Now, Rogo is my mother's maiden name although it's spelled a bit differently.
So, when I first met Scott back in the 1970s, naturally I'd mention the fact that my mother's
maiden name was very close to the way he spelled his own name, just he didn't have the “w”
at the end.
I explained that my mother's family, her father in fact, had been born in the city of Bialystok
in Poland.
He told me that his family also came from Poland.
Of course, when families came to the United States and they entered through Ellis Island,
the officials there would give their foreign names English spelling.
So, it's very likely that two related Rogo's might have had their family name spelled somewhat
differently if they came over at different times in English.
He told me that according to his family tradition, the family was originally from Spain and had
immigrated to Poland in the 15th century as a result of the Spanish Inquisition.
So, we treated each other as if we were distant cousins.
We had every reason to think that, although we never traced a family genealogy to pin
it down exactly, we were probably related and we became close friends.
Now, I might mention that the Rogo side of my family is full of writers.
I've several cousins who have also published books, the poet Zackery Rogow, who is also
a translator, won the National Book Award for his translations of some of the writings
of Andre Breton, the French surrealist.
My cousin Miriam Rogow has written several mystery books and her mother Bobby Rogow,
Roberta Rogow, has also written some mystery books that have a kind of a humorous slant
to them as well.
So, it sort of felt natural to find another writer as a distant member of the Rogow branch
of my family.
Scott, as everybody called him, became one of the really great writers in the field of
parapsychology and was known especially as one of the leading historians in the field.
His book Parapsychology: A Century of Inquiry remains a classic.
But, what I admired him the most for was his willingness to probe areas of parapsychology
that other researchers shied away from.
He wrote books on poltergeists.
He wrote books on out of body experiences.
He wrote books on UFO contacts.
He wrote books on the strange inhabitants, magical creatures that might exist within
the Earth and delved into folklore.
Scott was trained actually as a musician and he played, as I recall, the French horn.
Sometimes, I believe he even performed as a substitute musician with the Los Angeles
Philharmonic.
His very first books, written when he was like twenty one years old, were about the
music, the sounds that people heard as they had out of body experiences, the various noises
or auditory sensations accompanying the outer body experience.
He actually created two volumes of this work.
Probably, his most infamous book was Phone Calls from the Dead.
I remember him telling me it oughta be a publicist’s dream.
In fact, he had a publicist who was very excited about it but it never really went that far.
It was a little bit too much for most people, although subsequently additional research
has been done on that very topic.
There's no doubt that Scott and his writing partner, Raymond Bayless, who was well-known
fine artists in the Los Angeles area where Scott lived, produced an important book.
In fact, many of his books today are still in print and are regarded as important and
valuable books.
It's not as if they have never been criticized.
Many parapsychologists took umbrage at Scott for various reasons.
He tended to get into quarrels with people; he liked a good argument.
He was often accused of being too credulous but I don't think that's necessarily the case.
He had a razor-sharp mind, actually.
But, he did support himself by writing these popular books.
That's how he earned his living and it's not an easy living to earn.
I don't know that any of his books were bestsellers but they were well written.
I remember on one occasion he told me the problem was he was writing so many of them
and getting them published at once - I think on one occasion, three or four in one year
- that he was becoming his own competition in that marketplace, and it's a narrow marketplace
for books of this sort.
Now, Scott was tragically murdered in 1990.
They found his body lying on the floor of his house soaked in blood.
He had been stabbed numerous times and it took quite a while for the police to nab anybody
in the murder.
In fact, I believe it was through the help of psychics.
I talked to one psychic, Allen Vaughn, now deceased, a good old friend of mine, about
whom I should prepare another “In Presence” monologue.
But, Alan told me that he had done a reading on the case and had suggested to the police
that there was a glass that had been left in a cabinet and it would have a fingerprint.
Apparently, that was used and a man was arrested and convicted for Scott Rogo's murder.
My understanding is this evidence provided by psychics was helpful to the police.
However, later on, the man who always proclaimed his innocence was released and his murder
conviction was overturned, apparently due to some technicality.
I think it said prosecutor misconduct.
So, technically speaking, as of this date, nearly 30 years later, the murder is still
unsolved, which is a great shame.
I would like to see some finality to the murder of my distant cousin.
What is the lesson in Scott's life for you?
After all, there are a lot of loose ends, so to speak.
He did accomplish a lot, I'll give him that, but his life was abruptly cut short.
Frankly, he's not the only friend I've ever had who ended up being murdered.
But, be that as it may, none of us know when our life might come to an abrupt end.
This is why my inner healing advisor, the ancient Roman philosopher, Seneca, once wrote,
“Live each day as if it was your last.”
So, let me leave you with this thought: If you were to live today and everyday as if
it were your last, without making any kind of dramatic and extreme changes, or maybe
you would, but what changes would you make?
Thank you for being with me.
